Articles/Unity-Asset-Package/index.html.title: Unity Asset Package | Inventory System Documentation
Articles/Unity-Asset-Package/index.html.keywords: Unity Asset Package DownUnder Studios sells system & tool Assets on the Unity Asset Store . These Asset Package are used either in-game or editor for game developers to implement & improve their game projects. Inventory Asset Package The Inventory Asset Package is an in-game system that is for game developers to implement an inventory system and controls into their game. Documentations can be found Here . How to install Here .

Articles/Unity-Asset-Package/Installatio.title: Installation Introduction | Inventory System Documentation
Articles/Unity-Asset-Package/Installatio.keywords: Installation Introduction How to Install If you haven't Purchased the package yet you can do so from the Unity Asset Store . then either one of two different ways to open the package. Either click " Open in Unity " button in the asset page in store. Or uses the package Manager. Use the package The best way to test the package is to open either the " Example Scenes " located in " Assets/DownUnder Studios/Scenes ".

Connect/Store.html.keywords: Store Unity Asset Store Inventory System Asset Package The Inventory System Package is a in-game system that is for game developers to implement an inventory system and controls into their game. The Inventory System uses the following Namespace: Inventory System Item System Utility System The Documentation related to the package can be downloaded in PDF Here . This Asset package can be purchased off of the Unity Asset Store .

Tutorials/UIToolkit/CodeReview.html.title: CodeReview | Inventory System Documentation
Tutorials/UIToolkit/CodeReview.html.keywords: CodeReview Author: Matthew Williams Date: 17/11/2021 Visual Element To be able to write code you need to understand how the code is written what can be used to make your UI I would always advocate using the UI Builder so you know how your UI looks at runtime, but there are some things that can done at runtime only, so you will need to understand the code you will be working with. Well start with the Visual Element as it is what all of the elements are derived from. Variables Transform  is of type ITransform which contains the position, rotation, scale & matrix. Visible  is whether the element is seen or not. Enabled Self  if this element is enabled or not. Enabled In Hierarchy  if this element is enabled or disabled by its Hierarchy. Picking Mode  if this element can be picked during mouse events or IPanel.pick queries. View Data Key  is data persistence such as scroll position & zoom level. Usage Hints  can only be set when not part of a panel. Is used to boost performance. None  not hint applicable. Dynamic Transform  is for an element that change its transformation often. Group Transform  is for an element that has many children that are Dynamic Transform. Mask Container  is for an element that operates with Overflow: hidden style. Dynamic Color  is for an element that changes any of its colors often. Hierarchy  is a struct listed below. Experimental  is for Transition Animations. Resolved Style  style values after layout pass. Tool Tips  when hovered over will display text informing what it is. Style Sheet  are for the uss files attached to this element. Style  is for the inline style of this element and overrides any other styles. Functions Add  adds a child to this element. Add To Class List  adds a class to this element. Bring To Front will move this element to the end of the list of children in its parent. Children  will return its children. Class List Contains  returns true if it contains the class Clear  removes all children from this element. Clear Class List  removes all classes from this element. Contains  returns true if this element is an ancestor of the child element. Contains Point  if this element intersects with the point. Element At  return the child at this index. Enable In Class List  will add or remove the class based on the Boolean. Find Common Ancestor  check closest ancestor that this and the other element share. Focus - is a sealed function that was inherited from Focusable class and isnt inheritable after visual element. Get Classes  returns a list of the classes. Index Of  returns and integer of the child or -1 if it isnt found. Insert  element at index. Mark Dirty Repaint  when triggered will force the element to refresh on next frame. Place Behind  will place this element behind its sibling. Place In Front  will place this element in front of its sibling. Remove  will remove this child. Remove At  will remove child at index. Remove From Hierarchy  will remove this element from its parent Send Event  will send an event to the event handler, this function is also sealed and cant be override from classes that inherit from this one. Send To Back  is the opposite from Bring to Front as it will move this element to the top of its parents children list. Set Enabled  same as Game objects Set Active function, disabled elements dont receive most events. Toggle In Class List  if the class exist then remove it, if the class doesnt exist then add it. Classes UXML Factory  Instantiates this visual element from the data stored in the UXML file. Inherits from UXMLFactory Type - is the parent class. UxmlTraits - is the next class. All that is required it the contractor. UXML Traits  Defines the UXML Traits for this element If you want to create your own elements you will need these 2 classes.

Tutorials/UIToolkit/Debugger.html.title: UI Toolkit Debugger | Inventory System Documentation
Tutorials/UIToolkit/Debugger.html.keywords: UI Toolkit Debugger Author: Matthew Williams Date: 17/11/2021 Location Unitys UI Debugger is a tool that can be used to debug your UI layout to help you find errors in your code. To find the Debugger Window -> Ui Toolkit -> Debugger & Event Debugger. Debugger The Debugger has a toolbar with a dropdown and 2 buttons, the drop down will select root elements, the first button is pick element when selected you can hover over elements and it will update UI Toolkit Debugger, the second button is show layout when selected will apply a box around each element inside of the root element to show the layout of the UI. 3 section the left is the hierarchy, top-right has the same tool as the web margin-border-padding rectangle UXML Dump classes, bottom-right has styles that can be change to the UI Element. All changes are temporary and when refresh/ deselected it will revert back. Event Debugger The Event Debugger has the same dropdown as the Debugger and a Search Field that list all of the Event types When a root element is selected it will show all selected events that are recorded and displayed in the events log each event has a time stamp the event type and the target of the event. When you select an event, it will show the event callbacks time stamp handler phase duration Event propagation paths, event information, registered event callbacks & event durations

Tutorials/UIToolkit/Introduction.html.title: UI Toolkit | Inventory System Documentation
Tutorials/UIToolkit/Introduction.html.keywords: UI Toolkit Author: Matthew Williams Date: 17/11/2021 Introduction This series will introduce you to the fundamentals of UI Toolkit, And will allow the user to produce new UIs for both runtime & editor. The rest of this introduction will provide you with working terminologies that will make understanding easier, As well as list a number of videos topics that will be touched upon. The following terminology will be the core of the UI Toolkit and not a complete list any additional terminology will be addressed in their corresponding videos. Terminologies Visual Element: Base class that all UI elements inherent from and are the main element used. UI Builder: The UI Builder lets you visually create and edit UI assets such as UI documents (.uxml files), and stylesheets (.uss files), that you use with Unitys UI Toolkit (formerly UIElements). UI Document: Is a Component that connects to a Game Objects. This makes it possible to render UI defined in UXML document in the Game view. Debugger: The UI debugger is a diagnostic tool that resembles a web browsers debugging view. Use it to explore a hierarchy of elements and get information about its underlying UXML structure and USS styles. UXML: Unity Extensible Markup Language (UXML) files are text files that define the structure of the user interface. USS: UI Toolkit supports style sheets written in USS (Unity style sheet). USS files are text files inspired by Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) from HTML. The USS format is similar to CSS, but USS includes overrides and customizations to work better with Unity. Videos There will be many videos such as a video on the UI Builder, where to find it and how to works. How to set the UI for runtime & editor window. How to debug existing UI with the included Debugger. How to structure your UI & code in different framework style(s). Reviewing the code structure of the UI system and how to access different parts thought code. Creating examples of common UI with UI Builder and how they would properly combine with code. There may be more videos in the future such as testing out experimental aspects when they are released such as Graph view and animations.

Tutorials/UIToolkit/Setup.html.title: Setup | Inventory System Documentation
Tutorials/UIToolkit/Setup.html.keywords: Setup Author: Matthew Williams Date: 17/11/2021 Runtime UI First you need to right click the Hierarchy -> UI Toolkit -> UI Document When you create the Game object it comes with a Component called UI Document it has 3 exposed variables Called Panel Settings, Source Asset & Sort Order. If you created it though this method a Folder is added in your Assets called UI Toolkit it contains A panel Settings asset by the same name and a folder with a theme style sheet If the panel Settings is empty apply the panel settings file. Panel Settings the panel settings asset to be used to display the UI in its panel. The panel is what is rendered to the screen the Source Assets are added to the panel based on the sorting order and if it is a child object of another UI Document The Source Asset that requires a Visual Tree Asset is youre (.UXML) file Editor Window First you need to right click the Assets -> Create -> UI Toolkit -> Editor Window Then type the text into it you can choice if you want the uxml or uss but for the C# file is needed for the editor window unless you already have one and are going to attach a new uxml file to your existing C# file. When it is created the window will pop up and it will have 3 labels created 2 from the script (one with the uss attached) and the last 1 from the uxml document. This is the example they give you to teach the new editor windows style Open the C# script and you will see: It has using unity engine & editor UIElements as this is what UI Toolkit was originally called 3 functions the first is Show Example and has a menu item attribute and show where you can access the editor window And the function is the same as the original editor window Next is the Create GUI which is called when the window is opened the first line is the root element and it serves the same function as the panel settings. The next block of text is the first text label from the editor window that is added to the root element. Then comes the UXML that is imported from the asset and is in Instantiated and added to the root And the last block of code is the uss style sheet imported then a label is created the same way as the first but the stylesheet is added to the label which is added to the root As the editor window shows how the order, they are added to the root informs you that they will be loaded in 1 by 1. Editor First you need a C# script to edit for this example I will uses a basic player script with current/max health and level Next you need a folder called Editor so when you build your game its not included in the build as it may break your build. Then create a C# script with the suffix of Editor as it is a common practice so as to make sure you know it is an editor script You will need to add using UnityEngine.UIElements; & using UnityEditor.UIElements; Add the attribute above the class then replace MonoBehaviour with Editor [CustomEditor(typeof(*ScriptName*))] Editors have 2 functions called OnInspectorGUI & CreateInspectorGUI the first is the old function that allows for the editing of the scripts component in the inspector using the old method and the second is for new visual element it differs slightly from the editor window as it doesnt have a rootvisualelement that you add to, for the editor function it returns a visual element and that visual element will serve as the root element that you will add to. You can create your UI in the code here and add to your root visual element or you can create it in the UI Builder and add that to the root as I have done here. None of the buttons work as this is a demo I create to show how to works I will make this functional in a future example video and attach it to the in-game UI example that was shown.

Tutorials/UIToolkit/UIBuilder.html.title: UI Builder | Inventory System Documentation
Tutorials/UIToolkit/UIBuilder.html.keywords: UI Builder Author: Matthew Williams Date: 17/11/2021 Instructions The new UI Builder introduces is a tool that will allow you to create UI for runtime as well as for your editor. The UI Builder can be accessed via 2 different methods. Either method * Click the window tab. Scroll down till you find the UI Toolkit. Open it and located the UI Builder button and click. Or alternatively use method * If you have an existing visual asset tree (.uxml) double click and it will open the UI Builder. If you dont have a visual asset tree (.uxml) In the project section right click in the assets folder or folder of your choice. Create UI Toolkit UI document and that will create the visual asset tree (.uxml) file. When that is done open the UI Builder and I will show you a brief over view of the UI Builder layout as I will be going in to depth in subsequent videos in this series Layout The layout is split into 3 parts Middle The middle being the Viewport when you drag elements onto the canvas or add them to the hierarchy they will be displayed here Viewport the viewport contains several features file: can open, new, save, save as zoom: by percentage fit canvas: will type to fit your canvas to the screen it will shrink it unless it is set to match game view. Theme: set a theme for the canvas Preview: lets you preview how the canvas will work at when used of course functionality will not work. Settings: show UXML/ USS & Settings UXML/ USS: at the bottom will show you the code layout of the uxml & uss files. Right On the right side is the inspector when you have an element selected it will show 3 drop down tabs. Type the first one being type specific if you select a button, it will have button specific values and label will have label specific values, each element will have these values in common. Name: you can name the element and it will become an #Name that can be referenced in the stylesheet. View data key: used for view data persistence (i.e., tree expanded states, scroll position and zoom level). Picking mode: determines if this element can be picked during mouse events or Ipanel.pick queries Tool tip: when hover it will display a tool tip that can be used Using hints: offers a set of values that describe the intended usage patterns of a specific visual element it needs to be set before being add to a panel, as when its added it will effectively become read-only. Tab index: an integer used to sort focusable in the focus ring. Must be greater than or equal to zero. Focusable: a Boolean that if true will allow this element to be focused Stylesheet The second tab is the Stylesheet, it has a text box, 2 buttons and a drop-down tab. When you press the first button called Add style class to list it will take the text from the text box and add the class by that name for example Test will add. Test to this element. When you press the second button called Extract inline styles to new class it will take the changed values from the 3rd tab which I will get in a bit and create a new class for them named after the text from the text box. And lastly the drop-down tag called matching selectors when an .Class, #Name or Type matches the element it will show a drop-down tab that contains all of the style it will add to the element unless it is overwritten by Inlined Styles The last tab is inlined styles this tab contains a list of drop-down tabs that do various different changes to the element summarily to what CSS does to HTML as this new system take a lot of inspiration for its structure and style sheet. Display controls everything to do with the visual of the element. Position controls as its name suggests controls its position on the canvas Flex is for group element controls and spacing Align how the elements will be aligned on the canvas Size as its name would imply controls the sizes of the element min max and current size using either px, % The margin & padding works the same here as in CSS margins push other elements away from the current element and padding shrinks the element working space while maintaining its size Text is only used for elements such as the label that works with text Background you can set a color for the element add image and tint it to the background of the element Border like CSS will add borders around the element you can set a colour for each side its width and if the corners have a radius (curve) Transform controls the pivot point on the element, translate an offset position relative to were its located, change its scale and rotate around the pivot point Curser will change the mouse curser to the selected image when it is hovered over. Transition Animations allows you to create animation to the element. Left On the left side is the Stylesheet, Hierarchy, Library Stylesheets Stylesheet will allow you too create or import an existing style sheet (.uss) In the text box label Add new selector it will replace the text with a . And open a popup The popup will it will layout how to write your selector When you create a selector, you can click it an it will create 2 tabs in the inspector on the right The first tab is style selector and it contains the name of the selector and can be renamed here The last tab contains the same tabs as the inlined styles and will affect all element that implement this selector Hierarchy Hierarchy is the structure of starting off with the root ({name}.uxml) You can drag & drop elements from the library here to add them to the canvas and change its location in relation to the tree as a whole you have option when right clicking an element one of which is template it will take the element and its children and make a Visual tree asset (.uxml) file that contains the element and its children and can be located in the project button in the library. Library In the library tab it starts off with 2 buttons Standard & Project each containing tabs Standard With the standard button selected it shows 2 normal tabs and 5 editor only tabs that can be enabled by clicking on the root element and selecting the editor extension authoring Boolean in the inspector or in the Edit, Project Settings, UI Builder  enable editor extension authoring by default if this one is selected you will need to disable it in the UI Builder every time the editor only tabs cant be used in you game build As it stands the tabs are Containers, Controls for the normal tabs & the editor only tabs are Numeric Fields, Value Fields Choice Fields, Toolbar, inspectors Containers contains Visual element: this is the most basic of containers and is the base of all elements Scroll view: which functions the same as the legacy UI system. List View: which functions the same as the legacy UI system. IMGUI Container is the same as visual element but has focusable true Group box does the same as visual element but has 2 more variables binding path & text Bonding path is the path of the target property to be bound Text is just text and is affected but the Text option tab and effects its children if unset Controls these are the same as the legacy UI system Label button toggle scroller text field foldout slider slider(int) min max slider progress bar dropdown radio button & group Numeric fields for the editor only Integer float long progress bar vector2 vector 3 vector 4 rect bounds vector2(int) vector3(int) rect(int) bounds(int) object field Value field for the editor only Color curve gradient Choice field for editor only Enum tag mask layer layer mask Toolbar Toolbar Menu Button Spacer Toggle Breadcrumbs Search field Popup search field Inspectors Property field Project The project button shows all .UXML located inside of your project and some of these can be templates you have created for your project.

Tutorials/UIToolkit/Uss.html.title: Uss | Inventory System Documentation
Tutorials/UIToolkit/Uss.html.keywords: Uss Author: Matthew Williams Date: 17/11/2021 Introduction USS unity style sheet operate on the same Selector system as CSS by not as fleshed out. Like is CSS there is a hierarchy with goes * < Type < .Class < #Name < Inline-Style < Pseudo-Classes They way to think of it is the more specific the selector the more seniority it has. Selector * Root Selector This root selector matches to all elements and affect everything. Type The type of element such as Button this will affect all of the buttons. Type overrides the * universal selector .Class The Class is represented with the .ClassName controls all elements with class name attached. Class overrides Type Name | #ID The Name or (ID in CSS) is the name you give to an element(s) denoted by the #Name and any element with that name will be controlled by this. Name overrides Class Pseudo Classes Pseudo classes like in CSS can be attached to Type, Class, Name and will affect if conditions are met. :hover  when the mouse hovers over an element. :active  When an Element is active (can be Interacted with). :inactive  When an Element is inactive (cant be Interacted with). :focus  when an element is the current focus. :selected  This is not implemented yet. :disabled  When the element is Disabled. :enabled  When the element is enabled. :checked  When the element is toggled on. :root  This is different from the other Pseudo classes as it is used by its self to define the default style for the element the style sheet affects You can combine multiple of these selectors together like in CSS. Properties USS Data Types - Represents a distance value - Represents either an integer or a number with a fractional component. - Represents a whole number. - Represents a color. You can define with a #HexDecimal code, the rgb() or rgba()function, or a color keyword(for example blue or transparent). - Represents an asset in a Resources folder. - Represents an asset specified by a path. It can be expressed as either a relative path or an absolute path. USS Data Types UI Toolkit style properties use the same grammar syntax as W3C CSS documents: Keyword values appear as is. For example: auto, baseline. Basic data types appear between angle brackets ( < and >). For example: , . Non-terminals that share the same name as a property appear between angle brackets and single straight quotes ( <' and '>). For example, <'width'>. If a property value has more than one component: Side-by-side words mean that all of them must occur in the given order. A bar (|) separates two or more alternatives: exactly one must occur. A double bar (||) separates two or more options: one or more must occur, in any order. A double ampersand (&&) separates two or more components, all of which must occur, in any order. Square brackets ([ ]) denote grouping. Every type, keyword, or angle-bracketed group may be followed by modifiers: an asterisk (*) indicates that the preceding type, word, or group occurs zero or more times. a plus (+) indicates that the preceding type, word, or group occurs one or more times. a question mark (?) indicates that the preceding type, word, or group is optional. a pair of numbers in curly braces ({A,B}) indicates that the preceding type, word, or group occurs at least A and at most B times. USS custom Properties (Variables) Variables like in CSS it uses the prefix of double-hyphen--". For example color-1: red; It can be used by var() For example var(--color-1); Variables is declared in a selector and can b e used by any child selectors, it is common practice to uses the variable in the root selector (*) as all other selectors can uses it.
